reviewText:
Quake is a masterpiece, plain and simple.

Quake may be one of my favorite games, but I'll try to make this review as unbiased as possible. Created in 1996, Quake was revolutionary at the time. Following after Doom (Both created by the wonderful ID Software), Quake took all of what Doom did right and pushed it into the third dimension. The levels, music, and enemies all go beyond the call of duty and make this game a timeless classic.

Quake is heavily inspired by the works of H.P. Lovecraft, creating a dark and medieval setting. The dark shades of brown, green and bright reds in later levels really play to this note. This is not just to play homage to Lovecraft, but it doubles up as a way to put the player into an uneasy, unfamiliar, and terrifying world. Playing the game in linear order allows you to slowly creep into these unfamiliar waters. The levels are easy to commute, and allow for minor exploration to find secrets and health/ammo packs. When you run into a group of enemies, you rarely feel unprepared. That's not saying that this game is easy, because it'll tear you a new one if you don't watch out. This game isn't about unfairly pairing you with hard enemies; it’s about a gradual learning curve that teaches you to manage ammo, health and enemies.

The enemies in Quake are also inspired by Lovecraft's novels. Otherworldly beings with a cameo appearance by the “Lord of the Wood” are just a sampler of what you are in store for. Like I touched on in my levels section, the enemies never feel too tough to beat. The first enemies you'll face are dogs and soldiers, gradually building up to Fiends, Shamblers, and Spawns (Seriously, ♥♥♥♥ these guys). You are introduced to new weapons semi-regularly, and are given a good amount of time to find out what to use on the different enemies. An example (and quick tip) are the Zombies. You can mow the Zombies down with your shotgun, but after awhile they will stand back up to fight. Then how do you kill them? When the level first starts you are given a grenade launcher. The first enemies you see? Zombies. With this new weapon already ready to fire, you unload on the group to find that you gib (kill) the zombies for good. From that point on you know how to dispose of them, and that you shouldn't waste your grenades on enemies other than zombies (with an exception for tougher enemies).

With this dark fantasy world coming together with the level design and enemies, there's one last piece missing. Music. The music in Quake was composed by Nine-Inch-Nails. I'm not sure that I can say much else than that. The music fits the game perfectly with eerie, yet appropriate tracks. Take a look at the nail gun ammo boxes for a subtle nod.

Nobody is perfect, and sadly this port isn't an exception to that rule. The Steam version of Quake comes without the classic Nine-Inch-Nails soundtrack, and the mouse is locked horizontally. This is quickly fixed however by downloading this fix from the community page - http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=113166739

All in all, Quake is worth the $10 price tag normally, but is an absolute steal during sales, dropping to around $5. The amazing level design, challenging enemies, and great music all come together to create one of video game histories greatest. Never think that you are finished playing Quake. While the main story may have been finished, the lively modding community is doing its job to keep Quake alive. Brand new stories, fun game modes (Team Fortress 2 has roots set in Quake), and many more changes make this game that keeps on giving. I cannot recommend this game more, you'll have to try it for yourself.

The game itself gets all thumbs up, it's a true classic and one of the best games of all time. You don't get this sort of frenzied action and complex level design anymore, and it's wonderfully dark and gloomy.

Alone, the game's darkness can't really impress anymore, but with the soundtrack it really comes to life.

reviewText:
The early 90s was an interesting time for the FPS genre. The game most often given the title of the original first person shooter is Wolfenstein 3D, released in May of 1992 by id Software. This FPS is extremely primitive by today's standards, consisting of mostly barren environments with many repetitive sprites, but it left a strong impression on the gaming world as being an innovative and exciting game that made you feel like you were a soldier directly killing Nazis. Only eighteen months later, in December of 1993, id Software would revolutionize the gaming world with the quintessential DOOM, a much more detailed, aggressive, and yet comedic game than id's previous game. DOOM quickly became a beloved classic and was one of the most important, if not THE most important FPS of the 90s because of its refined controls, weapon variety, unique environments, hellish setting, memorable music, comedic value, and bright, cartoonish, characteristic and instantly recognizable art style. DOOM may have been gorier and superficially darker than W3D, but the game itself was quite bright and retained a simplistic manner that was palettable to audiences worldwide. Less than a year later, id Software released DOOM 2: Hell on Earth, a stylistically very similar game to its initial DOOM release, albeit with some graphical enhancements. The setting and weapons were similar and the game maintained its predecessor's cartoonish look and feel. There weren't many noticeable differences between the original game and its sequel, save for much better multiplayer and refinements to the original game.

Then, in June 1996, id Software released Quake. This game changed nearly everything from the DOOM playstyle. The gameplay was faster. Enemies were more nightmarish and unpredictable. The game used a 3D engine so the game actually gave the player a sense of depth and weight. The setting was dark, foreboding, and more in line with horror. The light/darkness was closer to depicting reality than a cartoon. Quake marked a definitive split from earlier ventures into the FPS genre by giving the player a sense of fear, urgency, and panic. Dark, unrelenting, and frightening for the time, this game took everything comedic from the DOOM franchise (since the series was goofy, silly, and didn't take itself that seriously) and reversed it. It added an actual atmosphere and made a tonal shift from light-hearted goofiness to the grittiness of a biting underworld.

As with DOOM and W3D, the goal of Quake is usually to find a key to open up a passage to progress in order to find another key to open up a new area to find yet another key. Yet the enemy placement, labyrinthine level design, and brutal gameplay keeps this seemingly repetitive task from becoming stale. Every section is different and you'll often have the challenge of simply figuring out where to go, what to do, and how to deal with the enemies you're faced with without dying. Sure, DOOM presented some challenges but the enemies always stood out from the environment and had simple-to-memorize patterns, and you generally had enough space to strafe to avoid enemy projectiles. Quake changed this by making the environments more confined (or feel more confined), the level design less straightforward, and enemies don't stand out as much and behave somewhat unpredictably or in ways that can be frustrating to counter. Quake is a fantastic model for how games SHOULD be made: challenging, maintaining a consistent and clear tone, requiring players to think, and never being unfair.

After Quake, id Software could never again recapture the intensity or ferocity of this gem. Quake II (1997) was, to me, a huge slap in the face, as it replaced the dark and serious tone of Quake with a silly, cartoonish, and completely out of place space marine story. In fact, the game itself was conceived as an entirely unrelated game, but because of the success of Quake, id decided to just make it a part of the series. To be honest, I never played Quake III until recently but since it was multiplayer-driven, I don't really include it as part of the series (if you want my opinion it just seems like a poor man's version of Unreal Tournament). Quake 4 was absolute trash and DOOM 3 was a major disappointment. I haven't tried id's most recent game, Rage, but I'm told it's incredibly buggy and just overall unpolished and derivative. It just goes to show not only that Quake was id Software's last great game, but that they truly lost something in their image of what their games should be like, instead going for bigger guns and more explosions and scripted events instead of heart-pounding dread and fast and furious gameplay.

This game contains something that id could never again recapture. Quake for me will always be about pure aggression, pure violence, pure intensity, and in its essence is the pure FPS. It may feel somewhat clunky nowadays (you will need to change things around in the settings if you've played any FPS's in the last 15 years), and the enemies aren't the most detailed (okay, they're downright ugly by today's standards) but in practice you will see that it is one of the most refined games, fusing fast and unforgiving gameplay with a dark and chilling atmosphere. In my personal list of top FPS games, it ranks at number 4 behind (1) Aliens versus Predator 99/Gold Edition, (2) Half-Life, and (3) Unreal Tournament.

The best word to me that sums up Quake is intense. It is a fantastic game that, while perhaps not the most innovative game of the 90s, is beyond a shadow of a doubt one of the most important. It helped to shape other FPS's to come in the late 90s, the glory years of the genre, which would come to a sad and ignominious end at the turn of the millennium.

Quake is the legendary old-school first person shooter from ID Software that was a step up from Doom as a true 3D game. The controls are simple, move, strafe, shoot, jump and change weapons. It is fast paced and you can strafe avoid most everything, so if you get hit, its your own fault. Because this is such a fast paced game, gone is the use button, instead you'll walk up to a button or a door and automatically interact with it.

As a shooter, Quake features a lot of guns such as double barreled shotguns, various versions of nail guns (machine guns), grenade and rocket launchers. The weapons feel nice and have great impact, everything from making an enemy fall backward to gib explosions everywhere! There are no throwable grenades or alt fire, but the weapons feel so good to use you won't need them.

You'll need the diverse array of weapons to take on an army of enemies in every level. Everything from standard soldiers and attack dogs to grenade launching chainsaw wielders and electric shocking giant yetis. There is a diverse array of enemies, that always keeps ramping up the challenge and tactics you'll need to kill them. The enemies will fight against one another, which is fun to see, but there aren't factions that you'll see intentionally compete against each other, but Quake still boils down to you vs everything else.

The levels are expertly designed, but can be overly brown, but I guess a game named Quake makes me think inner earth and inner earth makes me think brown. Each level will have you going up, down, forward, opening doors, finding keys, falling in traps, jumping over lava, finding secrets, swimming through ugly water, dodging enemies and murdering much more. It is not straight forward, but you won't get lost, because it is well designed. There are four episodes with 8 or so levels each. Not just that, but because this game is so old and was so wildly popular, it has a million mods and levels.

For new players, there is no regenerating health, but health and ammo are abundant, this is an action game. Kill an enemy, get rewarded with ammo. There is also armor that will let you take more damage.

The music was performed or designed by Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails and feels like a touch of ambiance amongst scratch guitars. The nail gun ammo also has NIN logos.

The Steam version of Quake offers QuakeWorld compatibility, but the big problem with that is QuakeWorld uses GameSpy servers, which were shut down. There are no achievements, but it is still a classic game that holds up today as one of the greatest old-school first person shooters.

In all this is a fantastic game that uses a game engine that spawned dozens of other engines.

If you loved DOOM or DOOM II then Quake is a god-send. The Original Quake was THE FIRST TRUE 3D First Person Shooter ever made. And it did (then as well as now, if anyone could see past then next CoD) phenominally.

Id Software's Quake is the game that popularised online deathmatches. This first game in the Quake series is inspired by Gothic-style environments, medieval settings and Satanic imagery (similar to id's predecessor, Doom). Though in order to get the soundtrack for the Steam version, you need the Ultimate Quake Patch.

Quake is also the game that the original Team Fortress was based on by John Cook and Robin Walker (who are now working in Valve).

Its singleplayer campaign consists of four episodes of eight levels each (including a secret level). You play a protaganist only known as Ranger sent into a portal to defeat an enemy codenamed Quake. As you collect weapons/items, they are carried over to the next level. The higher level you reach, the more challenging and intense it becomes than the last.

reviewText:
There could not have been a better time for a game like Quake to be launched than its own. Feeding upon the virtues and vision of Doom and Doom II, it reaches even farther confines of first-person gameplay, something it excels at, even if  compared to games of the same genre from years later. It is outstanding how well this behemoth of 1990s shooters has aged, since its frantic and well-balanced action gives way to countless reruns should the player wish to have some more of the Quake elixir. That could be explained by its advanced mechanics - quick strafing, jumping, recoil, plurality of enemies and plurality of ways to face them, among other gameplay qualities.

It could also be explained by its unparalleled level design, which may very well be the game's utmost asset. Here, names such as Tim Willits, John Romero, and American McGee spring to mind. Throughout Quake's four episodes, the player is challenged with labyrinthine keeps, gloomy catacombs, unforgettable halls... all of them filled with key areas that quickly swarm with just enough creatures to keep the protagonist busy and trigger-happy at all times. The bridges, narrow corridors, staircases, secret passages, underwater ruins, all respond to the player's arrival and can be revisited in punctual moments during the progression of the stage. Not to mention that each level has its own mechanisms of completion, often related to the acquisition of keys that open gates that give way to advanced rooms in the map. Never will a room, corridor, or any piece of game space feel redundant or undistinguished, as the game will give the player a purpose and leverage to keep progressing through the areas, using each level's singular rationale. Play maps like The Crypt of Decay (E2M3), The Vaults of Zin (E3M2), or The Wind Tunnels (E3M5), and have a wee glance at how memorable level design is here. Also multiplayer, still in its baby steps back then, provided great fun with maps like The Dark Zone (DM6). It is no Tokay's Tower, but it offers satisfactory deathmatch action.

This Steam version comes with four different applications that will behave distinctly depending on the system being used (two of them dedicated to QuakeWorld). Some resolution and colour issues hinder the experience more often than not, which is why the player should make sure to search for optimisation mods and patches online, such as the extremely efficient Ultimate Quake Patch v1.11, which works in perfect unison with the GLQuake application.

I find it nearly impossible not to value the game's momentous contributions to an almost perennial genre. It is unique in its techno-Gothic aesthetics and its veer towards an all-Lovecraftian story - with references spanning even post-Lovecraft Cthulhu Mythos bestiaries, such as the Chthonians - while staying simplistic and not bothering the player with plotline complexities, which is understandable, considering the forthrightness of old-time shooters when it comes to writing. It is heart-warming to notice that almost twenty years have not stained the delight of mouse-and-keyboard frenzy that Quake inspires.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Best power-up, Quad Damage = max fun gibbing demons. Also telefrag = pro final boss fight.

Not the very first first-person shooter ever made, but close to it! If you do not own this game yet... well, where the hell have you been?! Ask a random person if they know of Quake and nine times out of ten they will. Quake's infamy knows no bounds, and for good reasons.

At its core, it's a demon slaughterfest. Run around finding keys and open up more levels  so you can blow up, pump full of shells, and even gib your enemies everywhere you find them.

It survives almost all versions of Windows over the years - in many cases fans themselves find their way around compatibility problems. You are given a few choices as to how to boot up your game of Quake on Steam. Just find whatever works best for you, experiment a little. The graphics are dated but playable, even more so with new resolutions available. On the plus side framerate will never be an issue here.

Enemies consist of all sorts of memorable foes: human grunts (enthralled or converted or something), vors, scrags, ogres - even yetis. Thankfully there's a nice selection of weapons and power-ups to help you wade through the carnage. Shotguns and double-barrelled shotguns, grenade and rocket launchers are all solid choices, but my favourite weapon would have to be the super nailgun. Yes, there are nailguns; a nod to Trent Reznor, who did the game's soundtrack. Why do I say this? The proof is on the ammo boxes of nails, for they bear his band's logo, NIN, better known as Nine Inch Nails.

Yet, for some reason or another the soundtrack is absent from the Steam version of Quake. Never fear! A quick download and patch can fix this - in the form of Ultimate Quake. Just Google it, easy fix.

I've mentioned some enemies briefly. What makes them all so special, huggable, and why play this instead of, say, DOOM?

The answer is fun factor. With game elements such as a yeti's projectile lightning, vor bombs (capable of turning corners!)ogre grenades and ridiculously high and long fiend jumps, there is a far easier time of getting demons to fight each other.. So forget trying to line up cacodemon cheese-and-bacon balls with a hell knight, Quake is where you crack open the popcorn.

But wait, there's more. Everyone's favourite power-up is the Quad Damage. The name is kind of hard to misconstrue. It goes without saying that they never last long enough either - once I get one I run around at top speed trying to find and kill everything in the level. Even the toughest foes flinch at a 4x damage hit from most weapons. One double-barrelled shottie blast at point-blank is... epic.

Other odds and ends: great enemy sound effects, they're all unique and specific to each enemy. Some damage flinches are golden too - the knight clutching his ear and stumbling always makes me grin. Good take on zombies too - kill them with anything other than explosions and they just keep getting back up again. Proof that explosions are f***ing awesome in everything you do. I'm pretty sure their attack is picking off a bit of their own brain and throwing it at you. Ew. But I guess they don't have any need for it!

Still further is the replayability. Finished Nightmare without saving and thought it was too easy? Join the speedrun community! It's crazy stuff, but great for a laugh. Rocket jumps (think: get hit by your own rocket or grenade) for boosting speed and getting to places that may seem like cheating is almost a sport in its own right.

Get this classic in your library and give it a gib. Rediscover the meaning of FPS fun.

reviewText:
This is one of the best games ever made, and certainly my favourite despite the huge number of other mind-numbingly awesome games I have played. Whilst the original game might not stand up in some ways to modern FPS games, its focus on simple satisfying carnage, and near total lack of a story or any semblance of realism to get in ther way of said carnage makes it one of the most pure and enjoyable FPS games in existence.

The main game is fairly short, but there are so many add-on levels and mods, you could easily be playing this for hundreds of hours without running out of new content. It also supports coop play, so you can blast through the main game and various mods together, and when you get sick of coop, you play one of the first ever deathmatch FPS games. Although Doom had deathmatch, it was Quake that caused an explosion in its popularity, and through mods spawned many new deathmatch modes, such as CTF and even Team Fortress.

Although there have been games since that have tried to bring players the classic gameplay focussed carnage of Quake and Doom, few have come anywhere near to the greatness of the originals. You'd be mad not to try this game if you've never played it before.

Disclaimer: I played Quake from 1996 when it came out. I still play now from time to time. I don't play the Steam version, hence I don't have much recorded playtime (just played ep1 to get enough to write this review! Still fun as hell).

Also, although the Steam version of the game works fine, I recommend getting hold of modern engine, such as Quakespasm to play it with. Check out the website Quaddicted to get new levels, mods and engines.

Quake is one of the best Id titles around. It has bad ♥♥♥ weapons, enemies, sound effects and music (provided by Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails).

It has very interesting level design that is a lot more advanced than Doom's. Each episode starts out in a military base that has a portal to other dimensions, so there's lots of variety in each episode.

The enemies range from grunts with shotguns to giants who shoot lightning, there's a lot of things in between.

Weapons are amazing, with sound effects that make them all seem very powerful. The weapons in Quake are all very useful for various situations, it is important to learn each weapons functionality.

Armor is a very important item in Quake. You die much quicker in Quake without armor than you do in other games from this time period, so always be well stocked up on armor.

My only complaints are that only the first episode ends in a boss fight, the rest do not, though the other 3 episodes are much harder than the first, still a boss fight for each rune would've been nice. Another thing, Quake has aged quite a bit, in the 90s Quake was a pretty scary game, but at least for me, its fear factor is no longer present.

A Steam version only complaint, Steam Quake doesn't loop the music tracks on its own, you must use a patched EXE and rip the CD audio to mp3 format to get it to work (there is a guide on Steam about how to do this). This should not be a problem, but it is, and it seems to be a problem that plagues not only Quake, but other CD audio based games such as Quake II, Hexen II, Blood, and more. There are no achievements, which doesn't bother me but it might bother others. I have yet to try online play with the Steam version so I have no real comment, but Quake multiplayer is amazing, I hope that it works on Steam.

If you like Doom, or other FPS games of the 90s, you'll love Quake.

reviewText:
Quake is a game that is difficult to describe accurately. It is an experience that takes everything you think you know about first person shooters gets thrown out the window and replaced by a new standard.

Quake is the first truly 3D first person game, no longer are the enemies and objects in the world represented by mere 2D sprites but are instead rendered in full glorious 3D letting you view them from every angle. This also opens up the maps and up, down, left and right are now all equal and most all be checked to find that one pesky monster shooting at you.

The weapons are plentiful and varied from the grenade launcher which, thanks to the 3D engine, can be used to bounce grenades off walls and ceilings to hit enemies that are hiding to the iconic lightning gun and extremely entertaining nail gun. All the weapons have excellent sound effects and animations and use them efficiently leaves you feeling powerful.

Using the weapons efficiently however requires more skill than ever before, aiming in the general direction of your enemies will not suffice and only a steady mouse hand will prevail against the alien hordes.

Map design is of an equally high quality with a great emphasis on atmospheric lightning and a decent about of nooks and crannies to find hidden goodies in. The multi-player maps are equally well balanced and will reward only the most skilled among you.

Throughout the maps, both single- and multi-player, you will encounter power-ups that grant you various short lived bonuses such as increased damage, more health, invisibility and other good stuff. Knowledge of their locations can quickly turn defeat into victory for the observant player.

Graphically there is not much to say. Quake simply sets the bar and it is up to the rest of the world to follow.

An excellent soundtrack sets the mood throughout the game and creates a dark and tense atmosphere that only increases as you progress through the levels.

All in all Quake is perhaps the greatest first person shooter every released simply because of how many firsts it can boast. Without it nothing would be the same and for that reason alone this is a game that no self respecting gamer can go without.

reviewText:
Brings me back to the good old days of when I had a 100MHz Pentium and 8 megs of RAM...  This game is great for what it does.  It shows where 3 dimensional first person shooters came from.  Yes, one can argue that the genre started with games such as Wolfenstein, Doom, or even Duke 3D...  But fully 3D enemies and environments started here.  Back when video cards were first starting to hit the market and everything was still being done on the CPU.

The CPU utilization of the game becomes apparent when you notice just how bad the animations truly are.  You'll first notice it with the dogs and the fact that their legs don't even have a full loop and they simply look silly when they run.  This is a very minor detail when you consider the game's mechanics.

The motion of the player is smooth and the guns shoot as you'd expect by today's standards.  This game set a standard that was long followed up until regenerative life was put into games.  I am hoping that the Doom reboot successfully brings the arena shooter genre back.  I appreciate a good story but the action in games of this caliber can make up for all that side ♥♥♥♥.  Let's face it, running around with a rocket launcher as your main weapon and blowing everything up is good for your stress and all kinds of fun at the same time.

Ultimately, Quake 1 is an insanely fun, action-packed FPS that I can do nothing but recommend to everyone who enjoys the FPS genre. reviewText:
Quake is a first person shooter that has you traveling through four different dimensions in search of runes that will allow you to fight the main villain. That is pretty much all the story you get and it is up to you to reach the end of each level until you retrieve a ruin and must go to the next dimension. You are free to choose whichever dimension to go to first but I suggest starting from left to right since that introduces all the weapons and enemies much more smoothly. Starting off you must walk into a portal to choose which difficulty you want and to select hard you have to jump over lava which was a nice touch. Your starting weapon is a shotgun, which sounds a lot more awesome than you may think since it is pretty much as useless as the pistol from Doom, disappointingly enough.

This is a very fast paced shooter where your moving speed is swifter than that of most games sprinting speed these days, which really comes in handy when there is an enemy pouncing toward you and another is shooting grenades at you. Learning an enemy and it's weaknesses is vital to surviving as you will be under attack by several different types of enemies at once and must learn to choose which one poses the biggest threat or simply how to spot an opening. Like in Doom they will also attack each other if they accidentally hit one another, and that can be very advantageous if you have enough skill to cause the enemies to fight each other to the death, as it saves you both ammo and the risk of taking them on yourself.  It is still exhilarating gameplay after all this time and is just as fun today as it was back then.

Environments are still rather acceptable and the atmosphere retains a strong horror vibe to it. Character models have not aged well at all and are rather laughable unfortunately. You will not have time to gawk at them though unless you want a chainsaw to the face. Enemies are pretty versatile since most have both a ranged and close quarters attack. An example is an enemy with a chainsaw attacked to it's arm that will use it when you get too close and a grenade launcher when you are at a distance. That is just one enemy, they usually through multiple types of monsters at you and adapting on the fly is the biggest part of winning a battle. All the enemies are instantly vastly different from one another and instantly recognizable which is a important thing in these type of games. Even a slime is more than capable of killing you if you are not careful.

That same level of awareness is necessary when traversing the levels. You are in their world and if something looks to good to be true it most likely is. One thing that I found strange at first is that there is no activate button and you most shoot or simply walk into to switches to activate them. I was unsure how to feel about this at first, but risking a bit of ammo to shoot something that looks out of place and suspicious to find hidden secrets did end up being much better than pressing your face against walls and mashing the activate key like in Doom. Level design is amazing in Quake and each level somehow manages to feel different than the last. The four dimensions do end up blending together in my mind though since they don't really have any real noticeable gimmicks to differentiate them from one another. There is an extra dimension to fight the bad guy but it is a tiny level and ended up being a very disappointing fight.

As mentioned before your basic weapon to fend off monsters is a underwhelming shotgun and a fire axe in case you are desperate. There is also a double barreled shotgun you come across later on but it is probably one of the most disappointing shotguns I have used in recent memory. It takes about 5-6 point blank shots to take out some of the most common enemies which makes the game feel bullet spongy  but worse still it burns through ammo which you can only carry 100 of that type. A huge disappointment after the legendary double barreled shotgun from Doom 2. Other weapons fair much better and are a lot more useful. There are two versions of guns that shoot nails and are very useful against enemies though ammo does go by quickly. Your most useful weapon will be a grenade launcher which outputs a huge amount of damage and ammo is plentiful though you will obviously not want to use it when enemies are close by.

As is typical from games of this era, there are health kits to replenish your health and armor pickups that will allow you to take more damage. There are other pickups like a hazmat suit that lets you walk on hazards, a quad damage pickup that allows you to completely dominate your foes , a protection pick up that makes you invulnerable for awhile and a golden ring that turns you invisible. Turning invisible sounds cool in theory but once you fire at an enemy they can see you perfectly and avoiding them may not be the wisest choice as you may be attacked by those same enemies if they hear a battle nearby. On the topic of sound one thing that must be mentioned is that the Steam version had all the music removed. I don't know why but if you do not want to mod it back in I wouldn't even bother playing this game.

Quake is still a very playable game if you can get past the dated graphics. It is unlike any other shooter released today and is an extinct brand of FPS which is a real shame. If you are buying it expecting multiplayer do know the community is dead and there are no bots so it all falls to the single player. One heck of a campaign though and it should last you about 6 hours. There is no real reason to play it again other than for fun or wanting to try the hidden difficulty mode. It is a perfect game to pick up and play when you are bored since most levels are only 10 to 15 minutes long. If you are on the look out for some fast paced FPS action or simply want to see why the Quake series is held in such high regards by most, Quake 1 is highly recommended.

reviewText:
In the 1990s, the first-person shooter was still a new genre to many, and id Software were the kings of the genre. Starting by introducing many to the genre with Wolfenstein 3-D, id created a shooter that had the player running through a 3-D maze gunning down Nazis and killing Hitler, and it was really all people needed in 1992. The next year, id got a little more ambitious and unleashed Doom onto the world. Allowing players more weapons and adding a vertical axis to the game, Doom took gaming by storm, with gamers all too happy to dismember the armies of Hell and play with their friends online (it got so popular many offices had to install programs onto the computers that could prevent people from playing Doom deathmatches because so many people slacked off and went online fragging each other in deathmatch.) Doom got a sequel, which got two expansions endorsed but not made by id, and a collection of levels created by fans of the games were released. It seemed like id had peaked and that there was nowhere else for id to go from here. But then Quake happened.

Quake again redefined what it meant to be a FPS and shocked the gaming world by adding a truly 3-D environment that was filled with all kinds of unique and varying types of enemies. With 4 episodes and 7 levels each, the game is smaller than Doom, but the gameplay is off the hook, balls-to-the-wall, rocket-jumping, grenade-hopping, MADNESS. There's a less overt evil you see in Quake compared to Doom, as these aren't just Demons from hell, they're inspired from H.P. Lovecraft, Edgar Allen Poe, and other classical horror works. While it's lacking in the epic-boss-encounter department, the game is more concerned with being a damn good shooter, and it certainly accomplishes that. I've been playing Doom and Wolfenstein for quite some time now, but Quake is better than both those games and I've only been playing it for about 3 hours, which is saying a lot because I've played over 500 hours of Doom (don't check the Steam hours, I use GZDoom.)

If you like first person shooters, buy Quake. You'd be doing yourself a favor.

A very important game in gaming history. It added and extra dimension when it came to FPS's and it was a landmark achievement at the time. Today, however, the third dimension is used in pretty much every game now, but Quake still holds up as a whole. It plays like a silky-smooth old-school FPS with deep/nonlinear level exploration, fast-paced projectile dodging, and a variety of differentweapons and powerups used to kill a variety of  monsters. If you like old-school FPS games, you'll love this.

There is one major flaw however, one massive issue that brings the whole game down, and it's not Quake's fault, it's Steam's. There is none of the original music. When Quake was orignally released, there were two discs: one with the game, and one with the music. When they released it onto Steam, they didn't bother putting the music in with it. Why? Id Software may have moved on to bigger things with Rage, but plans for Doom 4 make me believe that a new Quake may lurk somewhere beyond the horizon. It's important to know your roots in gaming, and while I got my online start in Starsiege: Tribes, my favorite singleplayer FPS of yore was probably Quake, if not Half-Life. Quake gave me my love of shotguns and grenade launchers and if an FPS cannot deliver me satisfying examples of such, then it does not measure up to my expectations for what constitutes adequate firepower. reviewText:
Quake.

If you’re here, the odds that you know what Quake is are pretty significant, so this review might seem a little (or quite a bit) pointless.

But, Quake has a special meaning to me – Quake and I go way back, it being one of the first games I would ever play, along with Half-life and Doom. I still remember those days, zipping around those moody corridors and those dank, decrepit hallways, filling everything that moved with as many rounds as my 6-year-old hands were able to pump out...

Before inevitably dying at the hands of some monstrosity, of course.

Sure, I wasn’t good at it by any conceivable degree, but damn, I still loved it. It was more than just a game to me, the environment, the enemy design – it all came together to create an experience that I just can’t seem to dig out of my head, not that I would ever want to. Even now, I still feel that urge to boot it up and shoot something.

I can’t promise that your time with Quake will be anything similar to mine, and you may find it to be dated, uninteresting or dull (and, in my opinion NONE of those things can define Quake). But to me, Quake will always be there, flashing through the back of my mind, making me feel the same way about it as I did 12 years ago, and because of that, I have no choice but to recommend it.

reviewText:
Quake was a great step up from DooM, the levels were in full 3D compared to DooM's 2.5D.
Although the animations look arround were very clunky and the AI is about as smart as an average console kid, if not slightly smarter which is understandable since it was one of the first games that did what Quake did.
The gameplay has had a few improvements, most of which are small but they are still improvements, some enemies had more than one attack.
Quake also had some basic object physics, grenades that bounce arround, fireballs that come out of lava and for the first time in a game things were affected by gravity, but gravity wasn't as complicated as say Half-Life.
Compared to DooM and DooM 2 this game doesn't have as many weapons, 8 in the base game and 9 or 10 in the mission packs.
Unlike DooM though the invisibilty powerups were actually useful.
Quake also had native multiplayer support, without the need of a source port like DooM 95 or ZDooM you could play online but finding a game outside your LAN server was hard, it was also possible to play the whole game cooperatively, although it probably wasn't as enjoyable it was there, aswell as a standard deathmatch gamemode.
In general this is a part of PC gaming history you can't miss so even if you play it once and forget about it buy it just so you can look back.

reviewText:
Quake is like Doom except the physics feel much nicer and you can jump, aim up and down and there's an increased emphasis on movement in general. The trade off is that there's smaller groups of enemies (rarely more than two at a time) and they're all a bit more bullet-spongey. The weapons can also be a tad unimaginative (no BFG here, just a gun that shoots lightning and chews through it's max amount of ammo in seconds).

A lot of people dislike this game's visuals for relying a lot on the color brown. Personally, I don't mind this, as I feel that the more complex lighting and architecture of the maps (compared to Doom) compensates for this. That and the crappy low-poly monster models (that are still surprisingly well animated) combine with the rusted look of the game to create a wonderful aesthetic of low-tech creepiness. (I'd compare it to Silent Hill, but no part of Quake is ever set in a foggy town in the countryside - though there is at least one user-made map set in Innsmouth.)

This game also has excellent sound design by NIN's Trent Reznor. Don't bother with that EpiQuake junk, the game's audio is perfect enough as it is ... and on that note, I have to explain exactly why I'm giving this a thumbs down, even though I've just been gushing about the game.

It's because the Steam version doesn't include Trent Reznor's ambient soundtrack that Quake played off it's CD as in-game music. Unlike Hexen, there aren't any MIDI tracks or anything for the game to fall back on if the CD is missing - just nothing. The in-game sounds of wind and flickering torches are slightly more audible, and that's as good a compromise as you get.

Now, I can understand the absence if it was a rights issue with Reznor, but that supposedly wasn't the case. Apparently, it was because when id put the Steam version of the game together (which runs in DOSBox) they couldn't figure out how to simply rip the tracks off the CD in OGG format and configure DOSBox to load those files in lieu of redbook audio. Maybe John Carmack was too busy working on his new engine for whatever that game no one cared about was called.

Regardless, get Quake if you can find the original CD release on the cheap - which you probably will, as it's not a particularly rare game, nor one as valued by collectors as Doom (though be careful not to buy a  shareware version by accident). Alternatively, wait and see if this ever shows up on GOG.com - as those guys will probably put more effort into a basic digital release of this game than it's own developers.

------------------

TL;DR, Quake is a very good game, but don't buy it here or you will get a version without music.

What's there to say about Quake? One of the most world-renowned and memorable FPS' of all time. But why is that the case? Let's take a detailed look and see:

1. Gameplay - Let's trim the fat and get right to the guts right off the bat; Quake's gameplay is that of your typical 90's old-school FPS: Fast, bloody, complex and hard as hell, and you will love it (if you're into FPS games, that is). You get a wide array of weapons from a harmless Axe to the dreaded Thunderbolt, which turns any enemy into mincemeat in seconds, including the dreaded Shambler. Also like any old-school FPS, it is rife with secret areas that are a chore to find, but well worth the rewards within! Most times, at least. Tons of pick ups like the Pentagram of Protection (Invulnerability), Ring of Shadows (Invisibility), and the all-too-memorable Quad Damage, allowing you to unleash doomsday to every enemy in sight -- and yourself, too, if you aren't careful! -- dealing a massive 400% damage with any weapon you choose! There is a wide variety of enemies you will also encounter, from the annoying Grunt to the creepy Vore. Hint: When you see a Fiend (the bipedal, ape-like thing with lacerator arms) run like hell. One leap attack, and you're near dead. No joke.

2. Graphics - Usually graphics aren't one thing to take too seriously in reviews. In my philosophy, so long as you can see where you are going, and nothing looks TOO pixelated, they're perfectly tolerable. Buuuuuuuuut, that being said, download the Ultimate Quake Patch to be able to play this game in buttery-smooth 1920x1080 (if you have a full HD monitor that is). Never before has a game from the 90's looked so crisp and clear. And to think at one point I thought the 320x240 resolution of Quake on the N64 was the best thing ever. *shudders*

3. Difficulty - Hoo, boy...if you are brave enough to play this game on Nightmare (which you should to get the full experience, as cliche as that may sound, I know), this game will keep you on the edge of your seat nearly at all times, especially once you start encountering the bigger, badder enemies in later levels. Also, beware the Spawns (the bouncy slime-things). Just...just trust me on this.

4. Replay value - I could start this beauty up and play it any day of the week and have fun with it. It's fast-paced, bloody FPS action at its finest, and one of the true granddaddies of the FPS genre, along with Doom, Wolfenstein 3D and Duke Nukem 3D.

Bottom Line: You want this game. It's usually like, $3 or something. Absolute steal and a half. As are the expansions! But I'll review those by themselves.

Ah, the Classic Quake. The first true 3D FPS game. 13 years on, how well has it aged?

Surprisingly well actually. I suppose the first thing to note is that the game played a lot like DooM, I personally like to consider it one of the 3 DooM 3's also consisting of DooM64 and the actual DooM 3. But I Digress.

Quake, as the first FPS to use actual Ploygons manages to hold up quite well, you have the basic DooM style controls, using the arrow keys to turn, Ctrl to shoot and WASD to move (That is unless you're using the Ultimate Quake Patch, but I'll get to that later). and it does feel like a well-rounded experience that manages to hold up today. Of course it has graphically aged poorly with Jerky animation (this can be fixed with the UQP) but to fully enjoy the game you have to put your mindset back in 1996 where the best looking 3D was Virtua Fighter, This game puts you in a realisting looking (for the time) environments and gives frigtening enemies that have never been seen before.

Story Wise the game doesn't offer much, but the game doesn't really need to, you're just a guy (Who I like to call Quakeguy) who must stop evil creatures from an Alternate Dimension. It is sweet and simple.

All weapons handle well, from the Shotgun, Nailgun, Their 'Super' Counterparts, Rocket Launcher, Grenade Launcher, all are simplistic in their design and manage to hit their target with a bit of help from auto aim (Again, UQP). The game features a fun Fast paced game that is perfect for speedrunners and delivers on the retro feeling and boasts great level design.

The Enemies themselves are actually made creepier with an effect that would not exist if the game had more polygons, The Gothic scenery makes the mood and feel of the game and gives the game It's own unique identity.

Unfortunatly the game has some problems cause by some sort of steam optimisation. The Music is Non-Existant, even though there exists OST tracks on YouTube, none are featured in this game. This is Where the Ultimate Quake Patch comes into effect. The UQP fixes a lot of the Steam problems as well as some more of the poorly aged parts: Enemies have now got fluent animation, Mouse Control is Enabled, Improved Lighting and Particle effects as well as the OST added. Personally though I thought the 1996 graphics and improved lighting and effects were too distracting and I had no idea how to get the game to look like the Original game with just the Soundtrack so I removed it.

The game still has a great Charm to it and is memorable for it's environments and enemies. The game is still fun without the UQP but may turn people off with the lack of soundtrack.

I suppose the bottom line is that Quake is a Good, if not Great game the has fun retro gameplay but naturally has not aged well in many areas. This leads to 3 possiblities for interest in the consumers purchase:
1) Buy the game on GOG where it (apparently) plays Just like the Steam release but with working OST
2) Buy on Steam with UQP, if you aren't bothered by the clashing graphics and enjoy updated versions of old games then this should be fine for you
3) Just buy the Steam release as it is and Play some 'Through the Fire and Flames' to the game and enjoy it for what it is.

Quake is a Landmark in the FPS genre that doesn't hold up as well as it's older brothers DooM and Wolfenstein but leaves it's mark in it's creative level design and fun fast gameplay.

Overview One of the oldest FPS' out there. Even to this day, the pixelated display (Which can be sorted with a retextured version named 'Quake Epsilon'), retro music, run and gun themes and level design still retain at least some of their widespread popularity. Definitely not for hipster gamers, who play their stupid little 2d pixel 'art' games, this is for real gamers who need a little trip down memory lane.

System Quake runs as it should, anything that causes too much trouble rarely occurs. The controls aren't too hard to master, plus they aren't buggy (As I've found with some other olden games). The controls aren't dissimilar from most modern-day games, with the exception of specialised buttons like turn left 5 degrees or something. It's just point and shoot. No need to reload.

Multiplayer The one thing that doesn't really work well in the original Quake is the co-op/multiplayer. It is usually pretty buggy and laggy, and controls have been known to break and/or unbind in a match. Plus, the multiplayer mechanics don't really gel with each other. Sometimes, the AI will just completely break down and enemies will just stare in the direction the editors placed them in and won't attack or move. This also means entities with any properties won't activate or do anything. The single player campaign is good enough on its own, however.

Conclusion This game is very good, considering the times it was made in. Newer versions have been released (The aforementioned Quake Epsilon) that make it easier to see what's actually happening. For such an old game, Quake still remains impressive and a fun experience. It may be like Destiny story-wise (It has none), but it certainly makes for a fun pick-up-and-play game when you're bored. 8/10.

Between Trent Reznor's minimalist soundtrack, and the gothic and occult themed art and design, you'll find yourself deeply uneasy. reviewText: The last hurrah of awesome from the doomed Carmack-Romero partnership that defined id software. Lovecraft-style horror and first person shooting never went together so great after this.

One of the single greatest FPSes ever made. This is an absolute classic that all fans of the genres must play, as revolutionary as Doom. Ah, the Classic Quake. The first true 3D FPS game. 13 years on, how well has it aged?

Surprisingly well actually. I suppose the first thing to note is that the game played a lot like DooM, I personally like to consider it one of the 3 DooM 3's also consisting of DooM64 and the actual DooM 3. But I Digress.

Quake, as the first FPS to use actual Ploygons manages to hold up quite well, you have the basic DooM style controls, using the arrow keys to turn, Ctrl to shoot and WASD to move (That is unless you're using the Ultimate Quake Patch, but I'll get to that later). and it does feel like a well-rounded experience that manages to hold up today. Of course it has graphically aged poorly with Jerky animation (this can be fixed with the UQP) but to fully enjoy the game you have to put your mindset back in 1996 where the best looking 3D was Virtua Fighter, This game puts you in a realisting looking (for the time) environments and gives frigtening enemies that have never been seen before.

Story Wise the game doesn't offer much, but the game doesn't really need to, you're just a guy (Who I like to call Quakeguy) who must stop evil creatures from an Alternate Dimension. It is sweet and simple.

All weapons handle well, from the Shotgun, Nailgun, Their 'Super' Counterparts, Rocket Launcher, Grenade Launcher, all are simplistic in their design and manage to hit their target with a bit of help from auto aim (Again, UQP). The game features a fun Fast paced game that is perfect for speedrunners and delivers on the retro feeling and boasts great level design.

The Enemies themselves are actually made creepier with an effect that would not exist if the game had more polygons, The Gothic scenery makes the mood and feel of the game and gives the game It's own unique identity.

Unfortunatly the game has some problems cause by some sort of steam optimisation. The Music is Non-Existant, even though there exists OST tracks on YouTube, none are featured in this game. This is Where the Ultimate Quake Patch comes into effect. The UQP fixes a lot of the Steam problems as well as some more of the poorly aged parts: Enemies have now got fluent animation, Mouse Control is Enabled, Improved Lighting and Particle effects as well as the OST added. Personally though I thought the 1996 graphics and improved lighting and effects were too distracting and I had no idea how to get the game to look like the Original game with just the Soundtrack so I removed it.

The game still has a great Charm to it and is memorable for it's environments and enemies. The game is still fun without the UQP but may turn people off with the lack of soundtrack.

I suppose the bottom line is that Quake is a Good, if not Great game the has fun retro gameplay but naturally has not aged well in many areas. This leads to 3 possiblities for interest in the consumers purchase:
1) Buy the game on GOG where it (apparently) plays Just like the Steam release but with working OST
2) Buy on Steam with UQP, if you aren't bothered by the clashing graphics and enjoy updated versions of old games then this should be fine for you
3) Just buy the Steam release as it is and Play some 'Through the Fire and Flames' to the game and enjoy it for what it is.

Quake is a Landmark in the FPS genre that doesn't hold up as well as it's older brothers DooM and Wolfenstein but leaves it's mark in it's creative level design and fun fast gameplay.

FINAL VERDICT: RECCOMEND

Overview One of the oldest FPS' out there. Even to this day, the pixelated display (Which can be sorted with a retextured version named 'Quake Epsilon'), retro music, run and gun themes and level design still retain at least some of their widespread popularity. Definitely not for hipster gamers, who play their stupid little 2d pixel 'art' games, this is for real gamers who need a little trip down memory lane.

System Quake runs as it should, anything that causes too much trouble rarely occurs. The controls aren't too hard to master, plus they aren't buggy (As I've found with some other olden games). The controls aren't dissimilar from most modern-day games, with the exception of specialised buttons like turn left 5 degrees or something. It's just point and shoot. No need to reload.

Multiplayer The one thing that doesn't really work well in the original Quake is the co-op/multiplayer. It is usually pretty buggy and laggy, and controls have been known to break and/or unbind in a match. Plus, the multiplayer mechanics don't really gel with each other. Sometimes, the AI will just completely break down and enemies will just stare in the direction the editors placed them in and won't attack or move. This also means entities with any properties won't activate or do anything. The single player campaign is good enough on its own, however.

Conclusion This game is very good, considering the times it was made in. Newer versions have been released (The aforementioned Quake Epsilon) that make it easier to see what's actually happening. For such an old game, Quake still remains impressive and a fun experience. It may be like Destiny story-wise (It has none), but it certainly makes for a fun pick-up-and-play game when you're bored. 8/10.

This game still stands as a unique, abstract shooter with a thickly-dark atmosphere.   No storyline; just a series of demonic mazes and fast action.  I lost much of my youth caught up in the multiplayer aspect of this game.  Gameplay-wise, it's a  basic but smooth formula.  It offers a challenge that is purely skill based; not just on your aim; but your timing, prediction and almost gymnastic movement around the levels.

I still think it's a technical marvel.  This was one of the first full-3D games; and the levels are deliberately vertical and abstract in their design.  Everything has long since been open sourced; as a coder it's intriguing to inspect the design from a kind of archeological perspective.

When starting, you're given the option to choose which executable to run;  QuakeWorld (which was its brilliant online version - though surely not noob friendly), didn't work for me.   Perhaps with some technical tinkering you can get this to work.  (It was never straightforward back in the day anyway)

I've tested the GLQuake option, is the hardware rendering option, this works without any issues.  I'm sure there are mods out there that improve the experience, though.

Gamers today will probably never feel the same sense of awe and wonder and compelling multiplayer gameplay as we did when it released.  I'm kinda glad that games have moved on though, this game has a slightly discomforting pull, like it's almost half-living, a demon demanding my return. What's there to say? Quake is one of the earliest First Person Shooters with a fully 3D world, items, and enemies. It hasn't aged quite as well as Doom in my opinion, but don't let that discourage you, quake knows what it is doing, and does it well. This game still stands as one of the most solid FPS experiences ever made, laying the foundation for many future games in the genre.

Quake plays similar to most of the original FPS games, you run around at a fast pace killing monsters, finding secrets, and collecting keys. It features the classic arsenal of shotguns, nailguns (basically machine guns), rocket launchers and more. The enemies and locations follow a medieval/dark magic theme, with a few futuristic settings here and there. This theme is pretty unique and isn't used for any of the sequels, in fact I'd go so far as to say that this game never got a true sequel.

The game's music was originally played from the disc so you will need to get a patch somewhere if you want it (The soundtrack was made by nine inch nails, it's worth your time).

There are some notable issues with the game however. I would not recommend playing the game as is when purchased. Go find a community made source port or patch, because it's not set up well for modern systems. It also crashes on rare occasions. One big issue is a bug involving runes. Quake has four runes which you must collect to enter the final area of the game, said runes will occasionally disappear when changing levels or respawning, this causes you to need to redo an entire episode of the game to get them back. The good news is that you can avoid this by making some extra backup saves here and there.

If you are looking for a classic key collecting and monster gibbing experience, then pick this sucker up and rocket jump to victory.
